content.webTitle: England’s George Kruis ready to lock horns with Paul O’Connell’s Ireland

fields.headline: England’s George Kruis ready to lock horns with Paul O’Connell’s Ireland
fields.bodyText: On paper it is an unfair contest. England’s George Kruis has started only twice for his country and now has to measure himself against the veteran Irish colossus Paul O’Connell and the 6ft 10in giant Devin Toner. Back in 2009 when O’Connell was captaining the Lions, Kruis was on a gap-year trip to South Africa with some mates from Dorking RFC. It just goes to show how dramatically sport’s wheel of fortune can turn. Kruis is now not just England’s starting lock – injuries to Courtney Lawes, Geoff Parling and Joe Launchbury having opened the door – but is rated among the fittest members of England’s squad. No one within the England squad is about to underestimate O’Connell before Sunday’s game in Dublin but, equally, the visiting front five do not look or sound remotely intimidated. The 25-year-old Kruis has already contributed to a fine win in intimidating surroundings in Cardiff and has also played Munster often enough to know exactly what is coming. How interesting, then, to hear him suggest England have the set-piece tools to sort out Ireland’s pack at the Aviva Stadium. “We do have a very good set piece and we don’t try to hide that fact,” stresses the Saracens forward. “It will be a big weapon of ours and hopefully we can deploy it.” Now 35 and entering the twilight of a wonderful career, O’Connell has heard such things before but Ireland have lost the last three fixtures between the two countries and memories of England’s scrummaging dominance at Twickenham in 2012 have not entirely faded. The England forwards coach Graham Rowntree has been delighted by the way Kruis has imposed himself at the highest level. “He is a very composed young man and I also love it in lineout meetings or in big team sessions when he stands up and tells us what we have to do, not arrogantly, but showing he understands his role,” Rowntree says. “He does his homework and that’s what gives him that confidence. I’ve been very impressed by him. From watching his performances, you wouldn’t underestimate him as an opponent. He deserves that respect.” Considering Kruis weighed only 92kg (14st 6lb) six years ago – he is now 116kg (18st 3lb) and 6ft 6in – his ascent in every sense has been remarkable. Even he concedes playing Test rugby was “a very distant dream” in 2009 when, as a teenager, he watched O’Connell and co from the Cape Town stands. “I was just joining Saracens and was rather underweight and not the best rugby player,” he says, reflecting on his days at Dorking in the shadows of the Wasps prop Jake Cooper-Woolley and the Surrey cricketer Jason Roy. “But I’d learned at school that you get places by working hard so I just thought I’d give it my absolute best. I began to see improvements quite quickly.” European showdowns with O’Connell and Munster have also played their part in accelerating his rugby education, particularly his first trip to Limerick. “I remember going there for my first or second Heineken Cup game and seeing Munster flags in the houses. For me it was a big eye-opener of how they support teams in Ireland. It was huge but I guess going there as an international team it will be that much bigger.” As for the mighty O’Connell, Kruis freely acknowledges there are few more influential warriors out there – “He is a clear talisman for Irish rugby … I have a huge amount of respect for him” – and Rowntree is equally conscious that England will have to replicate their impressive second-half effort in Cardiff to secure victory. “It’s a massive game and we’ll need a performance up there with that Welsh performance if we are going to get near to beating them,” says Rowntree, quietly confident England will not fold as they did when chasing the title in Dublin in 2011. “Our composure is better in terms of coming back after going behind. We’re a lot more settled and composed as a team. The art is not to chase the game too early and to stick to our plan. That was an issue in 2011.”
